theme: Hope in the midst of suffering—God's people are misunderstood minority exiles living under the rule of a different King, with persecution as an opportunity to show others the generous love of Jesus
structure: 1:3-2:10 A new family identity (new birth, living hope, chosen people)
2:11-4:11 Suffering as a witness to Jesus (submit to authorities, do good, follow Christ's example)
4:12-5:11 Suffering and future hope (fiery trial, judgment beginning with God's house)
5:12-14 Closing: Stand firm, greetings from Babylon (Rome)
messiahProfile: Suffering Servant who was rejected but chosen by God; Precious Cornerstone rejected by builders; Spotless Lamb whose blood redeems; Chief Shepherd who suffered, died, and was exalted to glory; the righteous One who suffered for the unrighteous to bring us to God
overview: Peter writes from Rome (which he calls 'Babylon') to churches scattered across Asia Minor (modern-day Turkey) who are suffering persecution for their faith. The letter shows that suffering for Jesus isn't a sign of God's absence but participation in Christ's own suffering, and that it leads to glory just as His did. Believers are 'exiles and strangers' in this world, but they have a living hope through Christ's resurrection and an inheritance that can never perish. Peter reframes suffering as witness—their good conduct in the face of hostility shows the world Christ's character.

1peter-1-greeting.title: Greeting: Chosen Exiles
1peter-1-greeting.speaker: Peter
1peter-1-greeting.audience: Elect exiles scattered throughout Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia
1peter-1-greeting.narrativeContext: Peter writes to churches facing hostility and persecution, establishing their identity before addressing their suffering.

expository.context: Opening greeting that establishes the theological foundation for the entire letter—believers' identity as chosen exiles.
expository.tension: How can we be both 'chosen' and 'exiles'? What does it mean to be scattered but elect?
expository.structure: v.1 (Peter to elect exiles of the dispersion), v.2 (Chosen according to foreknowledge of God, sanctified by the Spirit, for obedience and sprinkling with Jesus' blood)
expository.messiahProfile: Jesus Christ whose blood sprinkles believers for cleansing and covenant (echoing Exodus 24:8)
expository.messiahLink: Jesus' blood establishes the new covenant, marking believers as God's chosen people even while they live as exiles in the world
expository.notes: The 'dispersion' (diaspora) language evokes Israel's exile—Peter applies exodus/exile imagery to the church. Believers are chosen 'according to the foreknowledge of God the Father' (Trinitarian greeting: Father, Spirit, Son). The 'sprinkling with his blood' echoes both the Sinai covenant (Exodus 24:8) and Day of Atonement purification (Leviticus 16). This establishes their identity: they're God's chosen people living as exiles, sanctified by the Spirit, cleansed by Christ's blood. The five regions listed (Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, Bithynia) cover a vast area of Asia Minor, suggesting the letter circulated among multiple churches.

1peter-1-living-hope.title: Born Again to a Living Hope
1peter-1-living-hope.speaker: Peter
1peter-1-living-hope.narrativeContext: Peter opens with blessing/doxology, grounding believers' hope in Christ's resurrection before addressing their suffering.

expository.context: Peter writes to suffering Christians, but begins not with their pain but with God's mercy and the living hope secured by Christ's resurrection.
expository.tension: How do we endure suffering and persecution? What hope sustains us when the world hates us?
expository.structure: v.3-5 (New birth into living hope and imperishable inheritance), v.6-9 (Rejoicing through trials that prove faith genuine), v.10-12 (Salvation the prophets longed to understand)
expository.messiahProfile: The resurrected Christ who gives new birth into living hope; the promised Messiah the prophets searched for; the one whose sufferings and subsequent glories the Spirit predicted
expository.messiahLink: Jesus' resurrection is the foundation of living hope—it guarantees our inheritance is real, protected in heaven, and will be revealed at His return. His pattern of suffering → glory becomes our pattern. Peter, who denied Jesus and saw Him risen, now promises: your suffering has meaning and leads to glory.
expository.notes: Peter begins with hope (v.3), not suffering—the resurrection comes first. This is strategic: hope enables endurance. The 'living hope' (v.3) contrasts with dead/empty hope—it's alive because Christ is alive. The inheritance is 'imperishable, undefiled, and unfading' (v.4)—three negatives emphasizing permanence against decay, defilement, and loss. Believers are 'guarded by God's power through faith' (v.5)—double security: God's power + our faith. Suffering 'proves' faith genuine (v.7) like fire tests gold—it's not punishment but refinement. The 'end of your faith' (v.9) is 'salvation of your souls'—future consummation. Verses 10-12 show the prophets longed to see what believers now experience—the 'sufferings of Christ and the subsequent glories' (v.11) pattern the entire biblical story. Even angels long to look into these things (v.12).

prophetic.context: Peter strengthens believers facing persecution by anchoring their hope in resurrection reality.
prophetic.tension: Will suffering crush our faith or prove it genuine? Is our hope real or wishful thinking?
prophetic.structure: Resurrection hope (3-5) → Trial's purpose (6-9) → Prophetic anticipation (10-12)
prophetic.messiahProfile: The risen Christ whose resurrection secures living hope; the suffering-and-glorified Messiah the prophets foretold
prophetic.messiahLink: Jesus' resurrection proves suffering leads to glory—your grief is temporary, your joy will be inexpressible and full of glory
prophetic.notes: Strengthens: You're guarded by God's power (v.5)—your salvation is secure. Encourages: Rejoice even in trials (v.6)—they prove your faith is genuine. Consoles: Prophets longed for what you have (v.10-12)—you're living in the fulfillment they only glimpsed.

1peter-1-holy-conduct.title: Be Holy as God is Holy
1peter-1-holy-conduct.speaker: Peter
1peter-1-holy-conduct.narrativeContext: Based on the living hope, Peter calls believers to holiness and obedience as redeemed people.

expository.context: Peter transitions from theological foundation (resurrection hope) to ethical implication (holy living).
expository.tension: How should we live in light of our new identity? What does it mean to be holy as strangers and exiles?
expository.structure: v.13-16 (Set hope fully on grace; be holy in all conduct), v.17-21 (Live in fear during exile; ransomed by Christ's precious blood), v.22-25 (Love one another earnestly; born again through living word), 2:1-3 (Put away malice; crave pure spiritual milk)
expository.messiahProfile: The unblemished Lamb whose precious blood ransoms believers from futile ways (1:18-19); the one foreknown before the foundation of the world but revealed for believers (1:20)
expository.messiahLink: Jesus' blood is the ransom price—more precious than silver or gold—that purchases believers out of slavery to sin and makes them holy. His resurrection enables faith and hope in God (1:21).
expository.notes: The command 'be holy as I am holy' (v.16) quotes Leviticus 11:44-45, 19:2, 20:7—Peter applies Levitical holiness code to the church, the new people of God. The 'futile ways inherited from your forefathers' (v.18) likely refers to both pagan idolatry and Jewish legalism—both are empty compared to redemption in Christ. Christ as the Lamb (v.19) evokes Passover (Exodus 12) and Isaiah's Suffering Servant (Isaiah 53:7). He was 'foreknown before the foundation of the world' (v.20)—eternal plan, not afterthought. The call to 'love one another earnestly from a pure heart' (v.22) grounds ethics in regeneration—we can love because we've been born again. The 'living and abiding word' (v.23) contrasts with grass/flowers that wither (quoting Isaiah 40:6-8)—God's word endures, so those born by it endure. 'Taste that the Lord is good' (2:3) quotes Psalm 34:8, inviting ongoing experience of God's goodness through His word.

1peter-1-song-of-praise.title: Song of Praise: New Birth and Living Hope
1peter-1-song-of-praise.speaker: Peter
1peter-1-song-of-praise.narrativeContext: Peter's opening blessing functions as a song of praise, celebrating God's mercy and the living hope through resurrection.

expository.context: This passage is structured as a berakah (Hebrew blessing form)—'Blessed be the God and Father...'—celebrating what God has done in Christ.
expository.tension: In the midst of suffering, can we still praise God? What grounds our worship when life is hard?
expository.structure: v.3 (Blessed be God who caused us to be born again), v.3-5 (To living hope through resurrection, to imperishable inheritance), v.6-9 (Rejoicing even through trials), v.10-12 (Fulfillment of what prophets sought)
expository.messiahProfile: The resurrected Christ whose mercy gives new birth; the suffering and glorified Messiah revealed in time
expository.messiahLink: Jesus' resurrection is the cause for praise—it secures our living hope, guarantees our inheritance, and enables joy even in suffering
expository.notes: The poster shows this as a 'Song of Praise'—praise God who caused us to be born again into a living hope. The praise flows from theology: (1) God's great mercy (v.3), (2) New birth (regeneration), (3) Living hope (alive because Christ is alive), (4) Imperishable inheritance (v.4), (5) Suffering is a 'purifying fire' that tests and proves faith (v.7). Notice the Trinitarian structure: God the Father causes new birth, through Jesus' resurrection, by the Spirit (implied in sanctification, v.2). This isn't happy-clappy praise ignoring reality—it's defiant joy grounded in resurrection hope while acknowledging present grief (v.6).

prophetic.context: Peter uses doxology to strengthen, encourage, and console suffering believers.
prophetic.tension: Can we worship in the midst of trials? What sustains praise when persecuted?
prophetic.structure: Blessing (3) → Hope secured (3-5) → Joy in trials (6-9) → Prophetic fulfillment (10-12)
prophetic.messiahProfile: The risen Lord who grounds our praise and secures our hope
prophetic.messiahLink: Jesus' resurrection makes worship possible in suffering—praise flows from hope, not circumstances
prophetic.notes: Strengthens: Your inheritance is guarded in heaven (v.4)—nothing can touch it. Encourages: Rejoice in trials (v.6)—they're temporary and purposeful. Consoles: Even prophets longed for what you have (v.10-12)—you're not forgotten; you're privileged.

1peter-2-living-stones.title: Living Stones Built on the Cornerstone
1peter-2-living-stones.speaker: Peter
1peter-2-living-stones.narrativeContext: Peter describes the church's corporate identity as God's new temple, built on Christ the rejected cornerstone.

expository.context: Peter weaves together multiple OT texts to show believers are the new temple, the new Israel, built on Christ who was rejected by Israel but chosen by God.
expository.tension: If we're rejected and suffering, are we on the wrong path? How can we be God's people if the world—and religious leaders—hate us?
expository.structure: v.4-8 (Christ the living stone rejected by people but chosen by God; believers are living stones; those who reject Him stumble), v.9-10 (Corporate identity: chosen race, royal priesthood, holy nation, God's own people)
expository.messiahProfile: The Living Stone rejected by people but chosen and precious to God; the Cornerstone the builders rejected (Psalm 118:22); the Stone of stumbling and Rock of offense (Isaiah 8:14)
expository.messiahLink: Jesus is the rejected stone who became the cornerstone—His rejection by Israel's leaders wasn't failure but God's plan (Psalm 118:22). His exaltation after rejection becomes the pattern for His people. Believers are 'living stones' being built into a spiritual house on this foundation.
expository.notes: Peter masterfully weaves three OT stone texts: (1) Psalm 118:22—'The stone the builders rejected has become the cornerstone,' (2) Isaiah 28:16—'Behold, I am laying in Zion a stone, a cornerstone chosen and precious,' (3) Isaiah 8:14—'He will become a stone of stumbling and a rock of offense.' Jesus is simultaneously the precious cornerstone for believers and a stumbling stone for unbelievers. The 'spiritual house' (v.5) replaces the Jerusalem temple—believers are now God's dwelling place. The 'holy priesthood' (v.5) fulfills Exodus 19:6's promise that Israel would be 'a kingdom of priests'—now the church is that kingdom. Verse 9's fourfold identity—'chosen race, royal priesthood, holy nation, God's own people'—directly quotes Exodus 19:5-6 and Isaiah 43:20-21, transferring Israel's covenant identity to the church. 'Once you were not a people, but now you are God's people' (v.10) quotes Hosea 2:23—Gentiles are grafted in. The poster emphasizes: believers are a 'new temple' (living stones), a 'kingdom of priests' (royal priesthood), and 'the holy people in the wilderness' (new exodus community).

narrative.storyPanels: Panel 1: Builders examining and rejecting a stone; Panel 2: God placing that same stone as the cornerstone; Panel 3: Builders stumbling over the rejected stone; Panel 4: Living stones being built into a spiritual house; Panel 5: Priests offering spiritual sacrifices
narrative.pattern: Rejection → Divine choice → Stumbling for some, foundation for others. What humans reject, God chooses. Christ's rejection becomes His exaltation; our rejection means we're on the right foundation.
narrative.messiahLink: Jesus is the pattern: rejected by religious leaders → chosen by God → exalted as cornerstone. Believers follow the same trajectory: rejected by the world → chosen by God → built into God's house.
narrative.notes: The stone imagery tells a story of reversal: what looked like rejection was actually God's plan. The 'builders' (Israel's leaders) rejected Jesus, but God made Him the cornerstone—the most important stone that determines the entire building's alignment. For those who believe, He's precious; for those who disobey, He's a stumbling stone. This narrative comforts persecuted believers: your rejection mirrors Christ's rejection, which means you're on the right foundation.

1peter-2-submission.title: Suffering as Witness to Jesus
1peter-2-submission.speaker: Peter
1peter-2-submission.narrativeContext: Peter transitions from identity to conduct—how exiles live in a hostile world as witnesses to Jesus.

expository.context: Peter addresses how Christians should respond to unjust treatment in the Roman Empire—submit to authorities, do good, follow Christ's example of suffering.
expository.tension: How do we live under hostile authorities? Should we resist or submit? What does faithful witness look like?
expository.structure: v.11-12 (Abstain from passions; conduct among Gentiles to glorify God), v.13-17 (Submit to governing authorities for the Lord's sake), v.18-20 (Household servants: endure unjust suffering), v.21-25 (Christ's example: suffered without retaliation, bore our sins)
expository.messiahProfile: The suffering Servant who did no sin, no deceit in His mouth; who when reviled did not revile in return; who bore our sins in His body on the tree; the Shepherd and Overseer of souls
expository.messiahLink: Jesus suffered unjustly without retaliation, entrusting Himself to God—this is the pattern for believers under persecution. His suffering accomplished salvation (bore our sins) and provides an example (follow in His steps).
expository.notes: The call to 'abstain from the passions of the flesh' (v.11) isn't just personal piety—it's witness. Gentiles watch believers' conduct and will 'glorify God on the day of visitation' (v.12) because of it. 'Submit to every human institution' (v.13) includes Roman authorities, even unjust ones—not because they're righteous but 'for the Lord's sake' (v.13). This is strategic witness, not passive acceptance of evil. The household code (v.18-25) addresses slaves specifically—Peter doesn't endorse slavery but shows how Christians in that position can witness through unjust suffering. Verses 21-25 are a sustained meditation on Isaiah 53 (the Suffering Servant): 'He committed no sin' (Isaiah 53:9), 'like a sheep that is led to the slaughter' (Isaiah 53:7), 'he bore our sins' (Isaiah 53:12). Christ's suffering is both example ('follow in his steps,' v.21) and atonement ('bore our sins,' v.24). We were 'straying like sheep' (Isaiah 53:6) but have returned to the 'Shepherd and Overseer' (v.25)—striking imagery of return from exile.

testimony.before: Before Christ, believers were like straying sheep—wounded by sin, wandering without direction, destined for death.
testimony.encounter: Christ bore our sins in His body on the tree—suffering unjustly, entrusting Himself to God, dying so we might live to righteousness. By His wounds we have been healed.
testimony.now: We have returned to the Shepherd and Overseer of our souls. We follow in His steps, enduring unjust suffering without retaliation, living as witnesses to His character.
testimony.messiahLink: Jesus is the suffering Shepherd whose wounds heal us and whose example shows us how to suffer faithfully as witnesses in a hostile world
testimony.notes: This passage works as testimony because it moves from lostness (straying sheep) through Christ's redemptive suffering (bore our sins) to transformed life (follow His steps, return to Shepherd). The wounds that heal (v.24) are paradoxical—His suffering brings our wholeness.

1peter-3-suffering-righteousness.title: Suffering for Doing Good
1peter-3-suffering-righteousness.speaker: Peter
1peter-3-suffering-righteousness.narrativeContext: Peter prepares believers for hostile questioning about their faith, pointing to Christ as the ultimate example of righteous suffering.

expository.context: Believers facing accusations and hostility need to know how to respond—both practically (give an answer) and theologically (understand Christ's suffering pattern).
expository.tension: Why suffer for doing good? How do we respond to accusers without fear? What does Christ's suffering have to do with ours?
expository.structure: v.13-17 (Blessed when suffering for righteousness; be ready to give gentle answer with good conscience), v.18-22 (Christ suffered for sins—righteous for unrighteous; now exalted with all authorities subject)
expository.messiahProfile: The righteous One who suffered once for sins, the unrighteous; put to death in the flesh but made alive in the spirit; proclaimed victory even to imprisoned spirits; now exalted at God's right hand with angels, authorities, and powers subject to Him
expository.messiahLink: Jesus is the pattern and power for faithful suffering: He suffered unjustly → died → was raised → proclaimed victory → exalted. Same pattern for believers. His suffering accomplished salvation (brought us to God); our suffering witnesses to that salvation.
expository.notes: Key verse: 'Even if you should suffer for righteousness' sake, you will be blessed' (v.14, echoing Jesus' Beatitudes). The command to 'have no fear' (v.14) quotes Isaiah 8:12-13—don't fear what they fear; fear (honor) Christ as Lord. 'Always being prepared to make a defense' (apologia, v.15) means having reasoned answers for the hope you have—but delivered with 'gentleness and respect' (v.15), not hostility. Keep a 'good conscience' (v.16) so accusers will be ashamed when they slander you. Verse 18: 'Christ also suffered once for sins, the righteous for the unrighteous, that he might bring us to God'—substitutionary atonement in a nutshell. The 'spirits in prison' (v.19) likely refers to fallen angels from Genesis 6/1 Enoch tradition—Christ's resurrection was a victory proclamation even to them. The Noah connection (v.20-21) shows baptism as symbolic entry into salvation through water—not washing body but 'appeal to God for good conscience' (v.21). Christ's exaltation (v.22) assures believers: suffering leads to glory. He's now 'at the right hand of God, with angels, authorities, and powers having been subjected to him'—cosmic victory over all spiritual powers.

prophetic.context: Peter strengthens believers facing accusations by showing Christ's suffering led to exaltation—same for them.
prophetic.tension: Will suffering for righteousness defeat us or vindicate us? Can we trust God when persecuted for doing good?
prophetic.structure: Blessing for righteous suffering (13-17) → Christ's pattern: suffering → death → resurrection → exaltation (18-22)
prophetic.messiahProfile: The exalted Christ who conquered death, proclaimed victory, and reigns over all powers
prophetic.messiahLink: Jesus' exaltation after suffering guarantees our vindication—suffering for righteousness is blessed because it leads to glory
prophetic.notes: Strengthens: Christ is at God's right hand with all powers subject (v.22)—you're on the winning side. Encourages: Be ready to give an answer (v.15)—your witness matters. Consoles: Suffering for righteousness is blessed (v.14)—it's the pathway to glory, not defeat.

1peter-4-fiery-trial.title: The Fiery Trial
1peter-4-fiery-trial.speaker: Peter
1peter-4-fiery-trial.narrativeContext: Peter addresses intensifying persecution ('fiery trial'), reframing it as participation in Christ's sufferings and judgment beginning with God's household.

expository.context: Persecution has intensified—Peter calls it a 'fiery trial.' Believers need to understand why this is happening and how to respond.
expository.tension: Why this intense suffering? Are we being punished? Should we be surprised? What does this mean about judgment?
expository.structure: v.12-13 (Don't be surprised by fiery trial—rejoice in sharing Christ's sufferings), v.14-16 (Blessed when insulted for Christ's name; don't suffer as criminal but as Christian), v.17-19 (Judgment begins with God's household; entrust souls to faithful Creator while doing good)
expository.messiahProfile: The suffering Christ in whose sufferings we participate now and whose glory we will share when it's revealed; the judge who begins judgment with His own household
expository.messiahLink: Jesus suffered, was glorified. We share His sufferings now (fiery trial), will share His glory then. Being insulted for Christ's name means the Spirit of glory rests on us. Our suffering is proof we belong to Him.
expository.notes: The 'fiery trial' (pýrōsis, v.12) refers to intense persecution—like gold refined by fire (1:7). Three responses: (1) Don't be surprised—suffering is normal for Christians; (2) Rejoice—you're sharing Christ's sufferings (v.13); (3) Rejoice even more when His glory is revealed (v.13). Suffering for 'the name' (v.14) means suffering specifically because you're a Christian—this is blessed because 'the Spirit of glory and of God rests upon you' (v.14). The warning about not suffering as a murderer, thief, evildoer, or 'meddler' (v.15) shows not all suffering is redemptive—only suffering 'as a Christian' (v.16). 'If it is time for judgment to begin at the household of God' (v.17) quotes Ezekiel 9:6—judgment starts with God's temple. If believers barely make it through this refining fire, 'what will become of the ungodly and the sinner?' (v.18, quoting Proverbs 11:31). Final exhortation: 'entrust your souls to a faithful Creator while doing good' (v.19)—active trust (doing good) while suffering.

prophetic.context: Peter speaks prophetically into their present suffering with both warning and promise.
prophetic.tension: Is this persecution a sign God has abandoned us? Or is it part of His plan?
prophetic.structure: Don't be surprised (12) → Rejoice in sharing sufferings (12-13) → Blessing of insult (14-16) → Judgment begins here (17-19)
prophetic.messiahProfile: The glorified Christ whose sufferings we share; the judge who refines His people first
prophetic.messiahLink: Jesus' pattern of suffering → glory becomes our pattern—present participation in His sufferings guarantees future participation in His glory
prophetic.notes: Strengthens: The Spirit of glory rests on you when insulted for Christ (v.14)—suffering proves you're His. Encourages: Judgment beginning with us shows we're God's household (v.17)—we're being refined, not rejected. Consoles: You're sharing Christ's sufferings (v.13)—not alone, and leading to glory.

1peter-5-resist-evil.title: Resist the Devil—God Will Restore You
1peter-5-resist-evil.speaker: Peter
1peter-5-resist-evil.narrativeContext: Peter's closing exhortations—humble yourself, resist the devil, trust that suffering is temporary and God will restore.

expository.context: Final pastoral encouragement as the letter closes—practical instructions for enduring suffering with hope.
expository.tension: How do we endure when persecution seems endless? What's our hope? How do we fight spiritual battle?
expository.structure: v.6-7 (Humble yourselves; cast anxieties on God), v.8-9 (Be sober-minded; resist devil who prowls like roaring lion), v.10-11 (God will restore, confirm, strengthen, establish you after brief suffering)
expository.messiahProfile: The God of all grace who called you to eternal glory in Christ; the one who will restore, confirm, strengthen, and establish after suffering
expository.messiahLink: Jesus is the means of calling ('in Christ') and the pattern—His brief suffering led to eternal glory, so will yours. God's grace sustains through suffering until restoration.
expository.notes: 'Humble yourselves under the mighty hand of God' (v.6) echoes James 4:10 and recalls OT imagery of God's sovereign power—He will exalt 'in due time' (kairos). 'Cast all your anxieties on him, because he cares for you' (v.7) quotes Psalm 55:22—practical trust in God's care. The enemy 'prowls around like a roaring lion, seeking someone to devour' (v.8)—vivid imagery of Satan's predatory intent. 'Resist him, firm in your faith' (v.9) shows resistance is active, not passive—standing firm while suffering. 'Your brotherhood throughout the world is undergoing the same kinds of suffering' (v.9)—you're not alone; this is global reality for Christians. The promise (v.10): 'After you have suffered a little while, the God of all grace...will himself restore, confirm, strengthen, and establish you'—four verbs of restoration showing suffering is temporary, restoration is God's work. 'To him be the dominion forever and ever. Amen' (v.11)—doxology concluding the letter's main body.

prophetic.context: Peter's final prophetic word—suffering is real but temporary; God will restore after refining.
prophetic.tension: Will suffering destroy us or refine us? Can we trust God's care when the devil prowls?
prophetic.structure: Humble trust (6-7) → Vigilant resistance (8-9) → Promised restoration (10-11)
prophetic.messiahProfile: The God of all grace who restores, confirms, strengthens, establishes after suffering
prophetic.messiahLink: Jesus modeled suffering → restoration; God will do the same for His people after a 'little while'
prophetic.notes: Strengthens: God cares for you (v.7)—cast anxieties on Him. Encourages: Resist the devil firm in faith (v.8-9)—active spiritual warfare. Consoles: Suffering is 'a little while' (v.10)—temporary, and God will restore you Himself.

1peter-5-closing.title: Closing: Stand Firm—Greetings from Babylon
1peter-5-closing.speaker: Peter
1peter-5-closing.narrativeContext: Peter's final greetings and location reveal—he writes from 'Babylon' (Rome), with Silvanus as scribe and Mark as companion.

expository.context: Letter conclusion revealing authorship details, location, and final exhortations.
expository.tension: Who wrote this? Where did it come from? What's the core message?
expository.structure: v.12 (Written by Silvanus; purpose: exhort and testify this is true grace—stand firm), v.13 (Greetings from 'she who is at Babylon' and Mark), v.14 (Greet one another with kiss of love; peace to all in Christ)
expository.messiahProfile: Christ in whom believers have peace; the one whose grace we stand firm in
expository.messiahLink: Jesus provides the grace that enables standing firm in suffering—the entire letter points to His sustaining power
expository.notes: 'By Silvanus' (v.12) likely means Silvanus (Silas from Acts 15-18, Paul's companion) served as Peter's scribe/secretary—explaining the excellent Greek style. Peter's purpose: 'I have written briefly to you, exhorting and declaring that this is the true grace of God. Stand firm in it' (v.12)—suffering while hoping in resurrection is true grace, not false grace that avoids suffering. 'She who is at Babylon' (v.13) is widely understood as the church at Rome—'Babylon' is code name (Revelation 17-18 uses same imagery for Rome). This confirms tradition that Peter ministered in Rome and was eventually martyred there. 'Mark, my son' (v.13) is John Mark from Acts 12-15, who wrote the Gospel of Mark—he's Peter's spiritual son and companion. The 'kiss of love' (v.14) was early Christian greeting practice. Final benediction: 'Peace to all of you who are in Christ Jesus' (v.14)—the shalom believers have in Christ despite external hostility.

author: Peter (Simon Peter, Cephas), with Silvanus (Silas) as scribe/secretary (5:12)
relationship: First letter from Peter to churches in Asia Minor. Written from Rome (called 'Babylon' in 5:13). Likely early-mid 60s AD, before Nero's persecution intensified. Peter mentions Mark as his companion (5:13)—the Gospel of Mark likely reflects Peter's eyewitness testimony. This letter precedes 2 Peter, which references 'the second letter I am writing to you' (2 Peter 3:1).
keyThemes: Believers as exiles and strangers—misunderstood minority (1:1, 2:11)
New identity: chosen people, royal priesthood, holy nation (2:9-10)
Christ the rejected cornerstone—believers as living stones (2:4-8)
Suffering as witness to Jesus' character and saving work (2:11-25)
Christ's pattern: suffering → death → resurrection → exaltation (3:18-22)
Persecution as participation in Christ's sufferings (4:12-19)
Fiery trial as purifying fire, not punishment (1:6-7, 4:12)
characterArcs: Peter: From denier who fled (Gospels) to bold witness who writes from Rome encouraging suffering believers; from Simon (natural) to Peter/Cephas (rock)—his own transformation grounds his authority to speak about suffering and restoration
Silvanus (Silas): Paul's companion in Acts 15-18, now Peter's scribe—bridges Pauline and Petrine traditions
Mark: Peter's spiritual son (5:13), Gospel writer who preserved Peter's eyewitness testimony
Believers: From 'not a people' to 'God's people' (2:10, quoting Hosea); from straying sheep to returned to Shepherd (2:25); from suffering exiles to future glory sharers (5:10)
Christ: The rejected stone → chosen cornerstone; the suffering servant → exalted Lord; the despised → the glorified
sermonPatterns: Hope → identity → conduct: Resurrection hope (1:3-12) establishes new identity (1:13-2:10) which shapes conduct (2:11-4:11)
Christ's pattern = our pattern: His suffering → glory becomes template for believers' suffering → glory
Suffering reframed: Not punishment but (1) participation in Christ's sufferings, (2) witness to the world, (3) purifying fire, (4) pathway to glory
Corporate identity: Extensive use of OT Israel language applied to the church—new exodus, new temple, new priesthood
Already/not yet: Already new birth and living hope; not yet full inheritance revealed—tension drives ethics
keyObservations: 1 Peter has the highest density of OT quotations per page of any NT book—Peter sees the church as the fulfillment of Israel's story
The letter structure mirrors exodus pattern: election → redemption (blood of lamb) → wilderness journey as exiles → promised inheritance
Peter's Greek is sophisticated, likely due to Silvanus as scribe (5:12)—much polished than 2 Peter's style
The 'Babylon' code for Rome (5:13) connects 1 Peter to Revelation's imagery and confirms Roman provenance
Three major OT stone texts woven together in 2:4-8 create a tapestry showing Christ as rejected-yet-chosen cornerstone
The household code (2:18-3:7) is unique—addresses slaves, wives, husbands but NOT masters or fathers—suggesting the churches were largely lower-class
Peter's eyewitness status (implied in 5:1, 'fellow elder and witness of Christ's sufferings') grounds his authority but he writes pastorally, not authoritatively
The 'spirits in prison' reference (3:19) is one of NT's most debated texts—likely refers to victory proclamation over fallen angels
Suffering vocabulary dominates: paschō (suffer) appears 12x; pathēma (suffering) 4x—more than any NT book per chapter
applicationForSpeechBuilder: Use 1 Peter to build speeches that: (1) reframe suffering as participation in Christ's sufferings and witness to His character, (2) ground believers' identity in corporate election and new birth, (3) show Christ's pattern (suffering → exaltation) as template for Christian life, (4) establish the church as new Israel—chosen people, royal priesthood, living temple built on Christ the cornerstone, (5) call believers to do good while suffering unjustly as witness strategy. The letter powerfully addresses persecution with hope anchored in resurrection, making it ideal for expository preaching on suffering, prophetic encouragement in trials, narrative retelling of Christ's victory pattern, and testimony of transformation from exile to belonging. Peter's pastoral tone combined with theological depth provides rich material for strengthening (you're secure in God's power), encouraging (your suffering has purpose), and consoling (restoration is coming after brief suffering).
